The sensitivities and specificities for the detection of @Disease$ were: subjective impression, 6 of 24 eyes (25.0%) and 52 of 80 eyes (65.0%); Amsler grid, 9 of 24 eyes (37.5%) and 59 of 80 eyes (73.8%); and @Diagnostic_tool$, 17 of 24 eyes (70.8%) and 44 of 80 (55.0%) eyes.

The sensitivities and specificities for the detection of @Disease$ were: subjective impression, 6 of 24 eyes (25.0%) and 52 of 80 eyes (65.0%); @Diagnostic_tool$, 9 of 24 eyes (37.5%) and 59 of 80 eyes (73.8%); and entoptic perimetry, 17 of 24 eyes (70.8%) and 44 of 80 (55.0%) eyes.

@Diagnostic_tool$ is 87% more sensitive than the subjective impression of visual decline (P  <  0.001) and 100% more sensitive than Amsler grid (P  <  0.001) for the detection of central scotomas in @Disease$ patients.

For the detection of @Disease$, entoptic perimetry is 183% more sensitive than subjective impression (P = 0.007) and 89% more sensitive than @Diagnostic_tool$ (P = 0.008).

To investigate the correlation between @Diagnostic_tool$ (FAF) and the results of spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) as well as visual acuity (VA) in patients with diabetic macular edema (@Disease$) and to determine the visual prognostic factors.

The strong association of FAF with SD-OCT parameters and VA in patients with DME could aid in the prediction of the restoration of photoreceptor integrity and subsequent visual recovery, especially in patients with @Disease$, in whom photoreceptor integrity before treatment could not be adequately evaluated, even with @Diagnostic_tool$.
